title: Crufts: Your ruff guide to the world's largest dog show
text:
Crufts: Your ruff guide to the world's largest dog show Everything you need to know about Crufts Credit: The Kennel Club Emily Allen 28 February 2017 • 6:18pm 
C rufts is almost back for 2017 so here's your guide to everything you need to know about the world famous dog show. When and where is it? 
The Crufts Dog Show runs from Thursday, March 9 to Sunday, March 12th at Birmingham's NEC. 
The much anticipated grand finale takes place at 8:30pm on the Sunday when the Best in Show will be crowned. 
The exhibition covers more than 25 acres of the NEC in Birmingham - about 14 football pitches - so make sure you've got some comfy shoes if you're planning on going. And the winner Crufts 2017 is...Monty Dogge....ah sorry wrong envelope #crufts #Oscars #montydogge pic.twitter.com/3WN8Z3P1hm — Monty Dogge (@Montydogge) February 27, 2017 How many dogs take part? 
A lmost 22,000 dogs will compete this year and 3,396 dogs from 47 overseas countries including Venezuela, Peru and the Philippines will compete at Crufts. 
This year there has been a 14 per cent increase of overseas entries compared to 2015. 
Dogs are judged in seven categories; Hounds, Gundogs, Terriers, utility breeds, working breeds, pastoral breeds and toy breeds. Crufts gallery How can I get tickets? 
A round 160,000 people are expected to come through the doors of the NEC over the course of the four days. 
Weekday tickets for the show cost £15 plus booking fee in advance, or £18 on the door. Weekend tickets cost from £17 in advance and £20 on the door. Best in Show tickets start from £17.50. Concessions are also available. 
Tickets are available from the official Crufts website , or by calling the Crufts Ticket Hotline at The Ticket Factory on 0844 338 0338. Crufts trivia Can I watch it on TV? 
Y es. Dog lovers can look forward to 11 and a half hours of television coverage when Crufts returns to Channel 4 and More4, fronted by Clare Balding. 
In addition to the traditional evening shows, Channel 4 will be broadcast an extra one-hour programme from the show in the afternoon on both Thursday and Friday. 
Here's when to switch on the telly: 
More4 Thursday 9 th March: 16.00-17.00 and 20.00-21.00 Friday 10 th March: 16.00-17.00 and 19.30-21.00 Saturday 11 th March: 19.00-21.00 Sunday 12 th March: 18.00-20.30 
If you're at work, you can always keep an eye on the action via the Crufts YouTube channel. Charles Cruft was a British showman who founded the Crufts dog show Who started Crufts? 
C rufts is named after its founder Charles Cruft who established the show in 1891. 
The young Charles left college in 1876 with no desire to join the family jewellery business. Instead he took a job with James Spratt who had set up a new venture in Holborn, London selling 'dog cakes'. 
Mr Cruft was ambitious was soon promoted to travelling salesman which brought him into contact with large estates and sporting kennels. He began travelling to Europe and in 1878 French dog breeders invited him to organise the promotion of the canine section of the Paris Exhibition. 
Back in England in 1886 he took up the management of the Allied Terrier Club Show at the Royal Aquarium, Westminster. It was in 1891 that the first Cruft's show was booked into the Royal Agricultural Hall in Islington and it has evolved ever since. A woman and her poodle at Crufts 2015 Credit: Carl Court/Getty Crufts controversies 
L ast year, Crufts was embroiled in a breeding row over footage of alleged deformities suffered by a dog which won best in breed. Officials admitted deliberately cutting footage from a broadcast of the prize-winning German shepherd with walking difficulties. 
In 2015, an Irish Setter named Jagger collapsed shortly after arriving back in Belgium after coming second in her class. An investigation found that Jagger had been poisoned. Many assumed he had been poisoned while at Crufts, but a later toxicology report revealed he was fed a fast-acting poison once in Belgium. 
At one show, judges were left shocked when they found a third testicle on a terrier . The owner had implanted a fake one (just one of the dog's testicles had descended into the scrotum and the judges required two on display), only to have the retained testicle drop during the show. The owner was banned from showing dogs for several years. Favourite British dogs gallery Famous winners 
T he 'Best in Show' title is awarded to the dog chosen as the winner of the entire show and was first awarded in 1928 to a fawn Greyhound named Primeley Sceptre. 
Only four dogs have won Best in Show on more than one occasion, and on three of these occasions they were English Cocker Spaniels owned by Herbert Summers Lloyd. 
The fourth winner was a Labrador Retriever called Bramshaw Bob, owned by Countess Lorna Howe (the second most successful breeder in the show's history.) Watch | Crufts 2016: Geordie Girl the Westie named Best in Show 01:23 
I n 2014, a Standard Poodle named Afterglow Maverick Sabre won Best in Show, while in 2015 a six-year-old Scottish Terrier called McVan's To Russia With Love was awarded the prestigious title. 
2016's winner was a little white Westie named Geordie Girl. The fluffy pooch, also known as Devon, became the first West Highland Terrier to win the top dog prize in 26 years. 
Other wonderfully named winners include Soletrader Peek A Boo (2013), Yakee A Dangerous Liaison (2003), Saredon Forever Young (1998), and Starlite Express at Valsett (1988). Follow the latest Telegraph Pets news READ MORE ABOUT:
